Hi, I'm Aaro — the developer of this app.

I created this to make accessibility information for public places in Switzerland 🇨🇭 easier to find and understand.

Most map services either ignore accessibility or simplify it to vague labels like "wheelchair accessible," which often isn't enough. For anyone with mobility challenges, details matter — steps, ramps, door widths, restrooms. This app is built to show those details clearly.

My goal is to offer highly detailed, accurate accessibility data for public places — starting in Switzerland.

Place data comes from OpenStreetMap (OSM), an open mapping platform. Since OSM data is often incomplete, I built and maintain an open-source database alongside it to capture more detailed accessibility information.

The idea is to go beyond yes-or-no labels, and show how accessible each place actually is.

This app is still early in development and lacks many features. There may be bugs, missing data, and things that need improving — and I\'m working on it whenever I have the time.\n\nUpdates will come over time, especially based on feedback. The goal is to keep it free, open, and useful.
The project is open source and available on GitHub, so if you have some improvement ideas or want to contribute feel free to open an issue or submit a pull requests. All help is appreciated.

This app uses Google Maps because of its stability and advanced features, which makes handling thousands of places in the map much more user friendly. Google Maps isn't free at scale though, so some usage limits may apply.

The backend and database are designed to work also within free tiers, as this project is built and maintained only by me for now. As long as there's no external funding, features and growth will be balanced with what's realistically sustainable.

Please note that the accessibility data in this app is based on open sources and contributions from users. While every effort is made to keep the information useful, accuracy cannot be guaranteed. The reliability of the data ultimately depends on the community. If you notice something missing or incorrect, please consider updating it in the app.
⚠️ Accessibility data may be incomplete or inaccurate. Help others by keeping it up to date.
If you have feedback, want to contribute, or just have a question, feel free to reach out to me.

A fully accessible place should have step-free access, wide doors, and enough space to move around independently. The entrance, indoor areas, and restroom all play a role in how usable a place is. Even if one of these works well, missing accessibility elsewhere can still make a visit difficult.

Indoor areas should be step-free and wide enough for a wheelchair to move and turn. Hallways should allow easy passage, and any changes in level should be covered with ramps or lifts. Narrow passages, internal stairs, or tight spaces can limit access even when the entrance is accessible.

The entrance should be level or have a ramp, with a door wide enough for wheelchair access. A minimum width of 90 cm is recommended. Small thresholds under 3 cm are generally fine, but anything higher may require a ramp. Automatic or easy-to-open doors improve access significantly.

In this field, you can add any extra details here that don\'t fit the standard categories.\n\nNote things like temporary obstacles, staff assistance, nearby parking, surface quality, or anything else that might help others understand the accessibility better.

An accessible restroom should have enough space to enter and move with a wheelchair, secure grab rails for support, and a toilet and sink that are easy to reach. The door should be wide enough, and features like an emergency alarm or Euro key access can also make a big difference. Even if a place is accessible overall, the lack of a usable restroom can still be a major barrier.

Step count refers to the number of steps at the entrance.

Zero steps usually means the entrance is fully accessible. A very small step under 3 cm is often still manageable with a wheelchair or walker.

One or two steps may be partially accessible, depending on height and context. Three or more steps typically make the entrance not accessible unless there is a ramp or lift.

Step height indicates how tall the highest step is at the entrance.

A threshold or step under 3 cm is generally still considered accessible. Steps between 3–10 cm may be manageable with help or a small ramp.

Anything above 10 cm is usually a barrier without a proper ramp or lift.

This indicates whether a ramp is available to bypass any steps.

To be accessible, a ramp should have a gentle slope (ideally 1:12), be wide enough for a wheelchair, have handrails, and a non-slip surface.

Even if a ramp exists, it may still be hard to use if it's too steep or narrow.

This tells whether a lift or platform lift is available to overcome vertical barriers like stairs.

Lifts are essential for accessibility in multi-level buildings.

It's helpful to know if the lift can be used independently or if it requires assistance or a key.

Entrance width refers to the width of the main access point or door into the building.

An accessible entrance typically has a clear width of at least 90 cm. Anything below 75 cm is usually too narrow for wheelchairs.

This helps determine if someone using mobility aids can get through the entrance comfortably.

Door type refers to how the door opens and how suitable it is for people with limited mobility.

Automatic sliding and automatic swinging doors are generally the most accessible, as they open without physical effort.

Manual swinging and manual sliding doors can be accessible if they are lightweight, easy to open, and have user-friendly handles.

Revolving doors, which rotate around a central axis, may require timing and coordination. Double doors, with two panels that open in the middle, can vary in accessibility depending on space and ease of use.

Door width determines whether a person using a wheelchair or walker can pass through comfortably.

A width of at least 90 cm is considered fully accessible. Widths between 75–89 cm may be manageable with smaller wheelchairs or with difficulty.

Anything below 75 cm is typically too narrow for safe access with mobility aids.

Room maneuver refers to the space inside a restroom or other accessible area to move and turn a wheelchair.

To be fully accessible, there should be enough space for a full 360-degree turn — usually a diameter of at least 150 cm.

Limited space can make it very difficult to use the room independently.

Grab rails provide support for transferring to and from the toilet or for general stability.

Accessible restrooms should have secure, horizontal and/or vertical rails placed next to the toilet and sometimes near the sink or door.

Missing or improperly placed rails can make the restroom difficult or dangerous to use.

The sink should be accessible from a seated position.

There should be clear space underneath for a wheelchair, and the faucet should be reachable and usable with limited hand strength.

Very high, deep, or obstructed sinks may not be accessible even if the rest of the restroom is.

The toilet seat height should be comfortable and safe for people transferring from a wheelchair.

Typically, a seat height of 45–50 cm is considered accessible. Seats that are too low or too high can make transfers difficult or risky.

Some accessible toilets may also include support backrests or additional features.

Emergency alarms allow users to call for help in case of an incident inside the restroom.

Accessible restrooms should have clearly marked alarm cords or buttons that are reachable from the toilet or floor level.

If no alarm is present or it's out of reach, it may not be safe for independent use.

A Euro key system is used across many European countries to allow access to locked accessible toilets.

If a place uses the Euro key system, users with a registered key can unlock and use the facility independently.

This can help ensure accessibility while keeping the facilities secure and clean.
